data.title: In the Shadow of the Abbey
data.meta_description: In which young Edwin takes a three hour bus ride to Whitby, locates Dracula’s tomb, and philosophises on the doings of Seagulls
data.text:
In which young Edwin takes a three hour bus ride to Whitby, locates Dracula’s tomb, and philosophises on the doings of Seagulls

There is something that is magnetic about the sea. The way that it moves up and down the shore, lapping toward the coast walls, is a sight for which there are not enough words. We must fall back on cliches and tired metaphor, wax lyrical on the limits of language in regards to the feelings that such places evoke. But we must describe it somehow. The draw to visit Whitby has been with me for the past couple of years and, due to a potent mixture of providence and inevitability, I have always managed to miss out on outings, days out, and all manner of other jaunts. But, coming out from the under the shadow of these days of plague, my friend Elliott and I finally found ourselves at Whitby.

The fog rolled over the moorlands and fields that surround the town, hiding the face of the North Sea beneath its opaque veil. What it was mourning I cannot imagine. We were sat on the Coastliner, having made our slow travel from the city of York, sat the back of the bus and laughing over an exclamation that one of the younger children had made concerning the similarities between Jesus Christ and the Prince Baphomet. Truly, this child was heading to the right place. We dipped down, following the road to Fylingdales and touching the very edge of Robin Hood’s Bay. This was the coastline of my childhood and adolescence, walking between that village and the Abbey, finding the remains of animals long since frozen in the rock. Passing…
